## Data Camp

Please finish up the following module

```{r eval = TRUE, echo = FALSE, message=FALSE}
dc_schedule <-  
  read_csv(here::here("content", "dc.csv"),
           show_col_types = FALSE) %>%
  as_tibble() %>%
  mutate(Required = case_when(
    Required == "checked" ~ as.character(fontawesome::fa("circle-check", fill = "#428bca", height = "15px")),
    Required == "unchecked" ~ as.character(fontawesome::fa("circle-xmark", fill = "#d9534f", height = "15px"))
              )) %>%
  mutate(Task = case_when(
    Task == "checked" ~ as.character(fontawesome::fa("circle-check", fill = "#428bca", height = "15px")),
    Task == "unchecked" ~ as.character(fontawesome::fa("circle-xmark", fill = "#d9534f", height = "15px"))
      )
    ) %>%
  filter(Week == 3) %>% #CHANGE HERE
  select(-Week) %>%
  mutate(across(everything(), as.character)) %>%
  mutate(across(everything(), str_squish)) %>%
  rename(`Due by` = Due) %>%
#  filter_all(any_vars(!is.na(.))) %>% 
  mutate(
    across(everything(), ~replace_na(.x, ""))
    ) %>%
  select_if(~!all(is.na(.))) %>%
  mutate(Module = paste0("<span style='color:#ffc787;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic'>", Module, "</span?"))
  
```

<center>
```{r message=FALSE, warning=FALSE, eval = TRUE, echo = FALSE}
kable(dc_schedule, 
      "html", 
      escape = FALSE,
      align = 'ccccll') %>%
  kable_paper(full_width = TRUE) %>%
  column_spec(1, width = "5em") %>%
  column_spec(2, width = "5em") %>%
  column_spec(3, width = "5em") %>%
  column_spec(4, width = "5em") %>%
  column_spec(5, width = "8em") %>%
  column_spec(6, width = "8em") %>%
  row_spec(0:nrow(dc_schedule), extra_css = 'vertical-align: middle !important;', color = "#f7f7f7", background = "transparent")
```
</center>

## R Task

Please follow the directions listed below

1. Download the task files

<center>
```{r echo=FALSE,eval=TRUE,message=FALSE}
loc <- here::here("static", "rtasks", "IntroductionToTheTidyverse.zip")

downloadthis::download_file(
  path = loc,
  output_name = "Introduction to the Tidyverse Task",
  button_label = "&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<span style='color:#ffffff'>Download</span>",
  button_type = "primary",
  has_icon = TRUE,
  icon = "fa fa-save",
  class = "hvr-sweep-to-left"
  )
```
</center>
<br>

2. [Unzip](/resources/unzipping) them on your computer

3. Open `Introduction to the Tidyverse install.R` and run everything inside of it

4. Open the file `Introduction to the Tidyverse walkthrough.Rmd` in RStudio

5. Click on Run Document, and then go through the walkthrough preferably in a larger window. To see how to do this, open the file `Introduction to the Tidyverse loading.gif` in the web browser of your choice or by another method to view the animated gif

6. After finishing the walkthrough, open the mostly empty script to `Introduction to the Tidyverse script.R` and load up the `tidyverse` library. *Please be aware that the needed libraries may not be provided for you in the future*

7. Keeping the hashtag, erase the words at the top and replace them with your full name

8. Load the `diamonds`^[Comes from the `ggplot2` package which is also in `tidyverse`] data set in the same way as `starwars` was shown in the walkthrough. Then recode the following values in the `cut` column in a new column named `cut_recoded`

    - **Ideal** with **5**
    - **Premium** with **4**
    - **Very Good** with **3**
    - **Good** with **2**
    - **Fair** with **1**
    <p style="margin-bottom:0.5cm;"></p>
    
    and everything else with **0**. Your output should consist of two columns - the unique original values and their respective recoding.

9. Save the file by adding your first initial and last name to the beginning of the filename. For example, my submission would be `aroy Introduction to the Tidyverse script.R`

10. Submit the script to <span style="color:#c563ff">Introduction to the Tidyverse</span> in the Submission Portal on [eCampus](https://ecampus.wvu.edu)

## <code><span style='font-size:20px'>esquisse</span></code>

This is optional, but will be helpful for many of you. If you would like to explore `ggplot2` using a more drag and drop approach, try the R package `esquisse`

<center>
```{r echo=FALSE,eval=TRUE,message=FALSE,purl=FALSE}
loc <- here::here("static", "rtasks", "Esquisse.zip")

downloadthis::download_file(
  path = loc,
  output_name = "Esquisse materials",
  button_label = "&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<span style='color:#ffffff'>Download</span>",
  button_type = "primary",
  has_icon = TRUE,
  icon = "fa fa-save",
  class = "hvr-sweep-to-left"
  )
```
</center>
<br>

After downloading and unzipping the file above, open up RStudio and run

<div class = "rounded">
```{r eval=FALSE}
install.packages("esquisse", dependencies = TRUE)
```
</div>

You'll also need to install the example data set [palmerpenguins](https://allisonhorst.github.io/palmerpenguins/articles/intro.html){target="_blank"} by running

<div class = "rounded">
```{r eval=FALSE}
install.packages("palmerpenguins", dependencies = TRUE)
```
</div>

If prompted, you may receive the option to restart RStudio. This is up to you, but unless you're already doing something else in RStudio, it can't hurt. After both install, run the following command

<div class = "rounded">
```{r eval=FALSE}
esquisse::esquisser(palmerpenguins::penguins)
```
</div>

<center>
![esquisse with palmerpenguins](/img/gifs/esquisse1.gif){width=85%}
</center>
If you want to use your own data set, run the following

<div class = "rounded">
```{r eval=FALSE}
esquisse::esquisser()
```
</div>

<center>
![esquisse with palmerpenguins](/img/gifs/esquisse2.gif){width=85%}
</center>
